results.title: Patsy Adam-Smith: author and social historian
results.creator_credit: Catherine South, Janet McLeod and Women's Program of the AFC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian women’s archival Series”.
An archival interview in which Patsy tells of her childhood, the inspirations for her books, her philosophy on oral history, her working methods, the adventure of her life at sea and her thoughts on love, children and marriage. Most of her books focus on the lives of ‘ordinary’ Australian working people, uncovering the unique history, folklore and lifestyle - the ‘real’ history of Australia, often lost in the overview of traditional history. Tagged as an ‘unconventional woman’, Patsy ignored the social rules of her day, and blithely worked in, sought out and wrote about the worlds in which women traditionally had no place.

results.title: Edna Ryan: a political life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian women’s archival Series”.
Born in 1904, working class politics surrounded Edna Ryan as she grew up in New South Wales. As a young adult she worked for the newly formed Communist Party until she was expelled. As a socialist in wartime she eventually found a new home in the Australian Labor Party. As a feminist, she became active in the industrial courts, in 1958 she became the first woman Deputy Mayor of NSW and played a significant role in 1974 in the fight for equal pay for women.

results.title: Helping hand
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Heart of the matter”.
Explains how current EEC policy of dumping surpluss food on Third World Countries simply encourages governments to do nothing about their own problems and that cash aid is preferable as it can be used to directly improve the infrastructure. Also the logistics involved in the distribution of EEC surplus in Ethiopia.

results.title: Search goes full circle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Search”.
This episode of the British television series “Search” looks at recycling waste materials in order to be more environmentally aware. Shows how to compost, make recyled paper and discusses the recycling of items such as cans, and second hand clothing which is made into a felt-like material and used as filling

group_works.title: Bahrain: The pearl of the Arabian Gulf
Tibet: the roof of the world

results.title: Tibet: the roof of the world
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Passport travellers’ guides”.
For many years, Tibet was a land shrouded in mystery, shadowed by the mighty Himalayas and closed to western travellers. This travelogue takes the viewer into the heart of Tibet and its people. From the wonderous Potola, once home to the Tibetan spirtual leader, the Dalai Lama, to the mountain herders and their yaks, to carpet factories where weavers work for months on elaborate designs, this is an incredible journey through a rugged landscape. The intensly spiritual nature of Tibetans and the incredibly beautiful monastaries and elaborate rituals which celebrate their faith are testimony to the country’s strong commitment to Buddhist principles.

group_siblings.title: Bahrain: The pearl of the Arabian Gulf

results.title: Bahrain: The pearl of the Arabian Gulf
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Passport travellers’ guides”.
Bahrain, an island nation in the Arabian Gulf, was once the capital of the pearl trade and was the site of the first oil discovery in the Gulf States. This includes an interview with the Amir of the State of Bahrain.

results.title: Guam: gateway to Micronesia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Passport travellers’ guides”.
Guam lies in the western reaches of the Pacific ocean. With its green rolling hills, soft trade winds, gleaming whilte sands, coral reefs and tranquil lagoons, Guam offers the idyllic escape.
